Problem:
Consider a scenario where the temperature distribution over a rod is governed by the heat equation \\(u_t = ku_{xx}\\), where \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity constant. We analyze the influence of a spatial transformation given by \\(g(x) = ax+b\\), where \\(a\\) and \\(b\\) are constants, on this temperature distribution.

If the transformation \\(g(x)\\) is applied to redefine the spatial coordinates at time \\(t = 0\\), and then the heat equation is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will the temperature distribution \\(u(x, t)\\) at time \\(t = T\\) be identical to the situation without applying \\(g\\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\(g(x)\\) changes the spatial configuration of initial temperature distribution. This initial modification influences the heat flow and the distribution over time under the heat equation, leading to a different temperature profile at any later time \\(t = T\\) compared to if \\(g(x)\\) was not applied.
